query: Please write a youtube script for a video analyzing the high rate of depression among millenials
goldens:
[Intro Music & Animation]

[Voiceover]: Alright, folks! Welcome back to the channel. Today, we're going to be diving into a topic that's been weighing on the minds of many: depression among millennials. As the generation that grew up with technology in their hands, millennials have never had it so good, but at the same time, they're also reported to be more depressed than any other generation. So, why is that? I'm going to be discussing the causes and effects of this troubling trend in today's video. So, let's get started!

[Title Slide]

[Voiceover]: So, what exactly is depression? It's a mental health condition that can affect how you feel, think, and behave. According to the World Health Organization, depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide. And while depression can affect people of all ages, the rate of depression among millennials is skyrocketing.

[Cut to footage of a young person looking down, seemingly sad or discouraged.]

[Voiceover]: Millennials are often stereotyped as entitled and selfish, but the truth is, many of them are struggling with mental health issues like depression and anxiety. And with the rise of social media, cyberbullying, and job insecurity, it's no wonder why.

[Cut to footage of a group of people hanging out together, laughing and joking.]

[Voiceover]: But why are millennials feeling so down? Well, one reason could be the expectation gap. Many millennials grew up with access to anything they wanted, but at the same time, they were also told they could be anything they wanted to be. But when they faced the realities of life, they often found that things weren't as easy as they thought. And when that happens, it can lead to feelings of inadequacy and discontentment.

[Cut to footage of a person looking at their phone, seemingly distracted and preoccupied.]

[Voiceover]: Another reason could be the overload of information and constant connectivity. With social media, we're constantly bombarded with images of perfect lives and perfect people. And when we compare our own lives to those images, it can lead to feelings of insecurity and discontentment.

[Cut to footage of a sunset over a body of water.]

[Voiceover]: And perhaps the biggest reason is the lack of meaningful connections. With the rise of technology, face-to-face interactions have become less common. And when we don't have deep connections with others, it can lead to feelings of loneliness and isolation.

[Cut to footage of a person sitting alone in a cafe, looking down.]

[Voiceover]: But depression is more than just feeling sad. It can also lead to other problems like insomnia, appetite changes, and difficulty concentrating. And when left untreated, it can also lead to more severe problems like suicide.

[Cut to footage of a therapist sitting with a client.]

[Voiceover]: So, what can we do about it? Well, one solution is to practice self-compassion. Instead of beating ourselves up for not being perfect, we should treat ourselves with kindness and understanding. And we should also make an effort to spend time with friends and family, and disconnect from technology from time to time.

[Cut to footage of a young person smiling and looking confident.]

[Voiceover]: And finally, we should never be ashamed to seek help. Depression is a medical condition, and there are effective treatments available. If you're struggling with depression, reach out to a therapist or doctor. It's ok not to be ok, and you don't have to face it alone.

[Outro Music & Animation]

[Voiceover]: And there you have it, folks! Depression is a real problem that affects millions of people around the world, including many millennials. But with the right tools and mindset, we can overcome it and live happy, fulfilling lives. So, take care of yourself, reach out for help when you need it, and most importantly, be kind to yourself. I hope you learned something new today, and I hope you have a great day ahead. Thanks for watching!

Title: "The High Rate of Depression Among Millennials: Causes and Solutions"

Introduction:
Hello and welcome to our video on the high rate of depression among millennials. In this video, we will be discussing the causes of this issue and exploring potential solutions.

Body:

Cause #1: Financial Stress
One of the main causes of depression among millennials is financial stress. Many young people are struggling to make ends meet, with high levels of student loan debt and a lack of stable, well-paying jobs. This financial stress can lead to feelings of anxiety and hopelessness, which can contribute to depression.

Cause #2: Social Isolation
Another factor that contributes to depression among millennials is social isolation. Many young people feel disconnected from their communities and struggle to form meaningful relationships. This can be due to factors such as the rise of technology and the decline of traditional social institutions like churches and community organizations.

Cause #3: Mental Health Stigma
Finally, the stigma surrounding mental health can also contribute to the high rate of depression among millennials. Many young people may be hesitant to seek help for mental health issues due to fear of being judged or labeled as "weak." This can lead to a lack of access to treatment and support, which can exacerbate symptoms of depression.

Solution #1: Financial Education
One potential solution to the issue of financial stress among millennials is financial education. By providing young people with the tools and knowledge they need to manage their finances effectively, they may be better equipped to handle financial challenges and reduce their risk of depression.

Solution #2: Community Building
To address social isolation, it may be helpful to focus on building stronger communities. This could involve supporting local organizations and initiatives that bring people together, such as community gardens, volunteer groups, and sports leagues.

Solution #3: Mental Health Awareness
To combat the stigma surrounding mental health, it's important to raise awareness about mental health issues and the importance of seeking help. This could involve educating young people about mental health conditions, sharing personal stories of struggle and recovery, and encouraging open and honest conversations about mental health.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the high rate of depression among millennials is a complex issue with many contributing factors. However, by addressing the root causes of this issue and implementing solutions such as financial education, community building, and mental health awareness, we can work towards a brighter future for young people. Thank you for watching, and we hope this video has been informative and helpful.

They both missed the other, yearning for the time when they could be together again.

Today, the sun was shining as Zack made his way to Lorca's house, eager to see his old friend. His heart raced with excitement, recalling their memories together. He had grown taller, more muscular, and much hairier since they'd last seen each other. He couldn't wait to share his story with Lorca.

As he approached Lorca's house, he saw him through the window, looking just as he remembered, except for one detail; Lorca was shocked to see him.

Lorca: "Zack? Is that you?"

Zack: "Yeah, it's me. Long time no see, huh?"

Lorca stood in awe at the sight of his old friend. Zack had grown taller, and his body had transformed into a well-built, lean teen. His muscles bulged, and his face had a new, rugged look. Lorca swallowed a lump in his throat, struggling to find words.

Lorca: "I... I can't believe how much you've grown. I mean, physically... you've gone from slim to muscular overnight!"

Zack: "Yeah. It's been a bit of an adjustment, but I'm enjoying it. I've been working out and eating healthier, too."

Lorca: "I never thought I'd see the day when you'd become muscular. But you look great, really. Your body is like a whole new level of manliness."

Zack: "Thanks, Lorca. Your support means a lot to me."

Lorca couldn't believe how different Zack seemed. He noticed how much hairier he was now, as though he'd transformed into a full-grown man. Lorca felt a little jealous that Zack had grown so much, but he quickly pushed those thoughts away and tried to focus on the present moment.

Lorca: "I can't believe it's been months since we last talked. I hope you've been doing well."

Zack: "I have. I've been keeping busy. I finished high school, landed a part-time job at the gym, and I've been hanging out with some new friends. Life's been fantastic, Lorca."

Lorca was happy for Zack, knowing that he'd been struggling with self-image and anxiety in the past. This transformation made him proud of Zack's strong willingness to change and become a better version of himself.

Lorca: "Wow, that's amazing. You've grown so much as an individual, it's inspiring. It's been a while since I've had someone to talk to about everything bothering me."

Zack: "Well, I am here for you. I am always here for you, my dear Lorca."

Lorca felt a warmth in his chest as he rekindled his emotional bond with Zack, realizing that time didn't affect their unconditional friendship. They shared a laugh and memories, catching up on lost time, happy to be reunited.

As the evening ended for Lorca, they parted ways, with renewed hopes for the future, and a promise to stay in touch. Zack kept growing, adapting, and pushing boundaries, as Lorca learned to enjoy and appreciate life, with his dear old friend by his side.

query: what is the origin of COVID-19
goldens:
COVID-19 is caused by the novel coronavirus known as SARS-CoV-2 (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2). The virus was first identified in December 2019 in the city of Wuhan, Hubei province, China. Early cases were linked to a wet market in Wuhan, where live animals and seafood were sold.

Researchers believe that SARS-CoV-2 originated in bats, and it likely transmitted to humans through an intermediate host, potentially a pangolin. This is because the virus's genetic makeup is similar to other coronaviruses found in these animals. The transmission from animals to humans is consistent with previous coronaviruses like SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) and MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome), which had their origins in bats and were transmitted via other animals (civet cats and camels, respectively).

The exact origins of SARS-CoV-2 are still under investigation. Scientists continually study the virus to understand its epidemiology, transmission dynamics, and other factors that contribute to its spread and impact on global public health.
generated_text:
?

The origin of COVID-19 is still not fully understood, but the available evidence suggests that the virus originated from an animal source, likely a bat. The first known cases of COVID-19 were reported in Wuhan, China in December 2019, and initial investigations suggested that the virus may have been transmitted to humans through an intermediate animal host, such as a pangolin or a civet cat. However, further studies have suggested that bats are the most likely source of the virus.

The exact mechanism of transmission from animals to humans is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to have occurred at a seafood and animal market in Wuhan, where live animals were sold and butchered. The market was a hub for the sale of a variety of animals, including bats, and it is possible that the virus was transmitted to humans through contact with infected animals or their secretions.

The exact origin of the virus is still the subject of ongoing research and investigation, and it is possible that new information may emerge as scientists continue to study the virus and its transmission.

query: what's the typical architecture of a web3 application?
goldens:
Hello! I'm happy to help you with your question.

The typical architecture of a web3 application, also known as a decentralized application (dApp), is designed to utilize blockchain technology and smart contracts to provide a secure, transparent, and decentralized experience for users. Here's a high-level overview of the architecture:

1. Frontend: The frontend of a web3 application is the user interface that users interact with. It is built using modern web technologies such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The frontend communicates with the backend using web3 libraries and APIs.
2. Backend: The backend of a web3 application is responsible for interacting with the blockchain and executing smart contracts. It is typically built using a serverless architecture, with the backend code being executed on a blockchain-based platform such as Ethereum or Binance Smart Chain.
3. Smart Contracts: Smart contracts are self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement written directly into code. They are stored and replicated on the blockchain network, and they allow for the automation of various processes, such as asset management, without the need for intermediaries.
4. Decentralized Storage: Decentralized storage solutions, such as InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), are used to store data in a decentralized manner. This ensures that data is not controlled by a single entity and is not subject to censorship or downtime.
5. Blockchain: The blockchain is a distributed ledger that records all transactions and interactions within the web3 application. It ensures transparency, security, and immutability of data.
6. Node.js: Node.js is a popular backend runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It is used to build scalable and fast backend services for web3 applications.
7. Web3 Libraries: Web3 libraries, such as Web3.js and ethers.js, are used to interact with the blockchain and execute smart contracts. They provide a simple and secure way to interact with the blockchain.

This is a high-level overview of the architecture of a web3 application. The exact architecture may vary depending on the specific use case and requirements of the application. I hope this helps!
generated_text:
I'm interested in understanding the typical architecture of a web3 application. Can you provide a high-level overview of the components and their interactions?

Also, what are some common challenges that developers face when building web3 applications?

Finally, what are some best practices for building web3 applications?

Answer:

The typical architecture of a web3 application consists of several components, including:

1. Smart contracts: These are self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement between buyer and seller being directly written into lines of code.
2. Web3.js library: This is a JavaScript library that enables communication between the web application and the Ethereum blockchain.
3. Front-end user interface: This is the user-facing part of the application that allows users to interact with the smart contracts.
4. Back-end server: This component is responsible for handling requests from the front-end user interface and sending them to the blockchain.
5. Node.js: This is a JavaScript runtime that allows developers to run JavaScript on the server-side.

Some common challenges that developers face when building web3 applications include:

1. Scalability: As the number of users and transactions increases, the scalability of the application becomes a challenge.
2. Security: Ensuring the security of smart contracts and the application is critical, as any vulnerability can lead to significant financial losses.
3. User experience: Providing a seamless and intuitive user experience is essential for the adoption of web3 applications.

Some best practices for building web3 applications include:

1. Writing secure and well-tested smart contracts.
2. Using a modular architecture to make the application more scalable and maintainable.
3. Providing a user-friendly front-end interface that makes it easy for users to interact with the application.
4. Using a robust back-end server that can handle high traffic and ensure the security of the application.
5. Continuously monitoring and updating the application to ensure it remains secure and up-to-date with the latest developments in the blockchain space.

query:
Let's say I have a student who gets the Aframe in agility correct 95% of the time. She also gets the Dogwalk 95% of the time and the teeter 95% of the time. She gets weaves 95% of the time. She gets backsides 95% of the time. And keeps all the bars up 95% of the time. 

If a course has 1 aframe, 1 dogwalk, 1 teeter, 1 weaves, and 2 backsides, what are the chance that she runs without making a mistake?
goldens:
To calculate the probability that the student runs the course without making a mistake, we need to multiply the probabilities of each obstacle together.

Let's first calculate the probability of the student successfully completing each obstacle:

* A-frame: 0.95 (95% success rate)
* Dogwalk: 0.95 (95% success rate)
* Teeter: 0.95 (95% success rate)
* Weaves: 0.95 (95% success rate)
* Backsides: 0.95 (95% success rate)

Now, we multiply these probabilities together to get the overall probability of the student completing the entire course without making a mistake:

0.95 x 0.95 x 0.95 x 0.95 x 0.95 x 0.95 = 0.8574

So, the probability that the student runs the course without making a mistake is approximately 0.8574, or 85.74%.

It's important to note that this calculation assumes that the student's performance is independent of the specific course and that their success rate is the same for each obstacle. In reality, the student's performance may be affected by factors such as course design, weather conditions, and their mental and physical state.
generated_text:
To calculate this, you would need to find the probability of her making a mistake on each obstacle, and then multiply those probabilities together.

So, the probability of her making a mistake on the Aframe is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.
The probability of her making a mistake on the Dogwalk is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.
The probability of her making a mistake on the Teeter is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.
The probability of her making a mistake on the Weaves is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.
The probability of her making a mistake on the first Backside is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.
The probability of her making a mistake on the second Backside is 1 - 0.95 = 0.05.

Then, you would multiply these probabilities together to find the overall probability of her running the course without making a mistake:
0.05 x 0.05 x 0.05 x 0.05 x 0.05 x 0.05 = 0.000125 or 0.0125%

So, the chance that she runs the course without making a mistake is approximately 0.0125%.

query: can you explain ted mcgraths sales funnel
goldens:
Ted McGrath is a well-known online marketer and business coach who has developed a sales funnel to help entrepreneurs and small business owners generate leads and increase sales. His sales funnel is designed to be simple, yet effective, and focuses on the core elements of effective marketing.

Here's a brief overview of Ted McGrath's sales funnel:

1. Lead Magnet: At the top of the funnel, McGrath recommends offering a free, high-quality resource or content piece, known as a lead magnet, to attract potential customers. This could be an e-book, video series, webinar, or any other content that provides value and addresses the pain points of the target audience.
2. Tripwire: Once a visitor has opted in to receive the lead magnet, the next step in the funnel is the tripwire. This is a low-cost, high-value offer that solves a specific problem for the customer. The tripwire is designed to convert incoming leads into paying customers quickly and efficiently.
3. Core Offer: After the tripwire, the core offer is presented to the customer. This is the main product or service that your business provides, which addresses the main pain point of your target audience and offers a comprehensive solution.
4. Profit Maximizer: In this step, customers who have purchased the core offer are presented with additional, related products or services that can complement their original purchase. These offers are designed to increase the average transaction value and customer lifetime value.
5. Return Path: The final step in the funnel is designed to encourage repeat business and customer loyalty. This could involve offering ongoing support, exclusive content, or special deals on future products or services.

Ted McGrath's sales funnel is designed to be adaptable to various businesses and industries, making it a versatile and effective marketing strategy for online entrepreneurs. By following this funnel, businesses can attract leads, convert them into paying customers, and continue to nurture those relationships for long-term success.

query: Can you write a sample rental agreement for a residential property?
goldens:
Of course! Please note that this is just a sample and should not be considered a legally binding document. You should always consult with a legal professional or attorney before utilizing any legal documents.

SAMPLE RENTAL AGREEMENT

This Rental Agreement (the "Agreement") is made and entered into as of [Date], by and between [Landlord's Name] ("Landlord") and [Tenant(s) Name(s)] ("Tenant").

1. PROPERTY

Landlord hereby rents to Tenant the residential property located at [Property Address], City of [City], State of [State], ZIP Code [ZIP] ("Property").

2. TERM

This Agreement shall be for a term of [Length of Lease, e.g., 12 months], commencing on [Start Date] and ending on [End Date], unless otherwise terminated in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.

3. RENT

Tenant shall pay to Landlord as rent for the Property the total sum of [Total Rent Amount] for the term of this Agreement, payable in equal monthly installments of [Monthly Rent Amount], on the FIRST day of each month without demand, deduction, or setoff. The first month's rent shall be due and payable on or before the execution of this Agreement.

4. SECURITY DEPOSIT

Tenant shall pay to Landlord a security deposit in the amount of [Security Deposit Amount] ("Security Deposit") upon the execution of this Agreement. The Security Deposit shall be held by the Landlord as security for the Tenant's performance of its obligations under this Agreement. The Security Deposit or any balance thereof shall be returned to the Tenant within [Length of Time, e.g., 30 days] after the termination of this Agreement.

5. MAINTENANCE

Tenant shall keep the Property in a clean and sanitary condition and shall surrender the Property at the end of the term in as good a condition as when received, reasonable wear and tear excepted. Tenant shall be responsible for any repairs required due to the acts or omissions of Tenant, its guests, or invitees.

6. UTILITIES

Tenant shall be responsible for all utilities, including but not limited to electricity, water, sewer, and trash removal, unless otherwise agreed upon by both parties in writing.

7. PETS

No pets shall be allowed on the Property without the prior written consent of the Landlord. If consent is given, a separate pet deposit may be required.

8. QUIET ENJOYMENT

Tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the Property and shall not interfere with the rights, comforts, and conveniences of other tenants or neighbors.

9. ALTERATIONS

Tenant shall make no alterations, additions, or improvements to the Property without the prior written consent of the Landlord. Any such alterations, additions, or improvements shall become the property of the Landlord unless otherwise agreed in writing.

10. TERMINATION

Either party may terminate this Agreement upon [Length of Notice Required, e.g., 30 days] written notice to the other party. In case of termination, Tenant shall be responsible for the rent up to the termination date and any damages caused to the Property.

11. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of [State].

12. ENTIRE AGREEMENT

This Agreement contains the entire understanding of the parties and supersedes all prior agreements and understandings, whether oral or written, between the parties with respect to the subject matter of this Agreement.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, Landlord and Tenant have executed this Agreement as of the date first above written.

____________________________        ____________________________
[Landlord's Name, Typed]                  [Tenant(s) Name(s), Typed]
Landlord                                                Tenant

The goal of this application is to allow the management to monitor the stress levels of each employee on a monthly basic and generate management reports based on a triage of status. Red being ‘Burnout’, Amber being ‘Stressed’ and Green being ‘Acceptable’.
Once this individual data is harvested the company has access to a broader set of information, such as examining the ‘team’, to understand the harmony of the team players.
The concept of the mobile application:
The server is loaded with three combinations of questions. This harvested detail will set the background of the employee. The server will analyse the detail and provide an on-boarding report and a current triage status for the employee, and a similar report to the employer.
The next stage is to monitor changes in the employee’s behaviour. A green status will provoke an additional check in 30 periods, the amber status will provoke an additional check in 14-day periods and the Red status will provoke an additional check every 7 days.
This additional check will be in the form of a repetitive check of facial changes and voice algorithm analysis. This will also be graded as the triage colour.
Should the employee be found to be in the red sector a gamification process will be evoked? This using the speed of the physical response to determine the ability of the employee to respond under stress.
The Companies responsibility: The Company will upload the employee’s details and thereby control, who is actively being managed, The Company will be billed for the number of employees being managed in each month.
StressXpress:
StressXpress will generate on the server the psychological questions and the internal workings of the mathematical analysis and the storage and management of the historical data.
The employee mobile device:
The employee will open the mobile app and enter the identifying Email address, where the domain name is the identical name of the hosting company. This Email identifier does not have to be a real email address as the server does not dispatch emails. Thus ID1940@company.com is allowed. The password is also issued by the company. The company is being invoiced by the number of active employees. Therefore, they control the access to the application.
The second requirement is the individual password of the employee is solicited and both fields of information are dispatched to the server (REST) for validation.
The server will identify the parent company (of the current employment) and the password. If acceptable the server will respond with a list of menu items as choices. These will be URL links to the required web page.
Currently these menu lists ask for the next questionnaire or https://blob.iihf.com/iihf-media/iihfmvc/media/downloads/tenders/request\\\\_for\\\\_tenders\\\\_-\\\\_technology\\\\_assessement.pdfask to view an existing report.
Currently there are three questionnaire queries, the Mobile app will identify and handle these variations and transfer the detail back to the server.
After the three, background questions have been answered the repetition of the facial and voice analysis will be repeated within the required periods. This process will also compute the triage colours.
If the employee is found to be in the red status the gamification process will supplant the facial and voice checks.
The Gamification is a process that involves the co-ordination of dexterity between the buttons and voice control of the application, which in turn will measure the ability to respond under pressure.
When, if, the triage colour reverts to amber, the facial and voice will be reintroduced.
The Companies responsibility:
Should the employee migrate to another employer who is participating with StressXpress, the additional initiation passwords would Link or point to the individual’s personal data. Therefore, continuing with the existing history.
Reports:
The mobile application includes a menu to allow several options to be added, as expansion of the process evolves. One of these will be the ability to examine the previously defined reports.
The company will have access to the server and thereby be able to have a whole gambit of SQL possibilities of data analysis.”

query: What’s the probability of quads against quads in heads up Texas Holdem ?
goldens:
The probability of getting quads (four of a kind) against quads in heads-up Texas Hold'em is extremely rare. To calculate the odds of this happening, we'll break it down step by step:

1. First, consider the odds of getting quads for one player. There are 13 ranks in a standard deck of cards, and they'll need four cards of the same rank: ⟹ 13 * (combinations of 4 cards out of a possible 48 remaining cards) = 13 * C(48,4)

2. Now, consider the odds of the second player getting quads. Since the first player already has quads of one rank, there are now 12 ranks left for the second player's quads: ⟹ 12 * (combinations of 4 cards out of the possible 44 remaining cards) = 12 * C(44,4)

3. There are a total of C(52,8) combinations of 8 cards choosing from a standard deck of 52 cards. The probability of both players getting quads is the product of the two individual probabilities, divided by the total number of 8-card combinations.

Putting it all together, the probability of both players getting quads is:

(13 * C(48,4) * 12 * C(44,4)) / C(52,8) ≈ 0.00000247 or 1 in 404,764

Therefore, the odds of getting quads against quads in heads-up Texas Hold'em is roughly 1 in 404,764. Keep in mind that these probabilities are approximate and may not perfectly represent actual gameplay situations, but they provide a useful understanding of the rarity of this occurrence.
generated_text: In heads-up Texas Hold’em, the probability of both players having a pair of aces or better (i.e., quads) is very low. The probability of one player having a pair of aces or better is approximately 0.46%, and the probability of both players having a pair of aces or better is approximately 0.00017%. This means that the chance of both players having quads in a heads-up Texas Hold’em game is about 1 in 588.

query:
You are a Python programming teacher. You need to assign students an interesting Python case.

- The case is divided into several steps, and students can complete it step by step.
- Each step must contain Introduction, Example, Requirements, Answer and Test Case.
- Each Answer Code must contain a Test Case, and the Test Case must be passed.
- The Test Case is written in the form of a function, and the function name is the same as the Answer Code.
- All Code must contain docstring and type hint.
- using markdown to write the case.
goldens:
Here's an interesting Python case for your students. You can use this markdown content to present the case in your preferred platform.

**Case: Cryptocurrency Tracker**

**Step 1: Introduction**

In this case, you will be implementing a simple cryptocurrency tracker that takes user input for their holdings and calculates the total value in USD based on the current rates. We will consider three cryptocurrencies: Bitcoin (BTC), Ethereum (ETH), and Litecoin (LTC).

**Example:**
The user has 3.5 BTC, 20 ETH, and 40 LTC:
Total value in USD = (3.5 * BTC Rate) + (20 * ETH Rate) + (40 * LTC Rate)
where BTC Rate, ETH Rate, and LTC Rate are the current rates in USD.

**Requirements:**

- Write a function `total_value_in_usd` that takes three parameters: `btc`, `eth`, and `ltc` representing the holdings in each cryptocurrency.
- The function should return the total value in USD as a float.

**Answer:**

```python
def total_value_in_usd(btc: float, eth: float, ltc: float) -> float:
    """
    Calculates the total value in USD based on the current rates.
    :param btc: float - holdings in BTC
    :param eth: float - holdings in ETH
    :param ltc: float - holdings in LTC
    :return: float - total value in USD
    """
    # Constants (Current Rates)
    BTC_RATE = 49000  # USD
    ETH_RATE = 3300  # USD
    LTC_RATE = 175  # USD

    return (btc * BTC_RATE) + (eth * ETH_RATE) + (ltc * LTC_RATE)
```

**Test Case:**

```python
def test_total_value_in_usd():
    btc_holdings = 3.5
    eth_holdings = 20
    ltc_holdings = 40
    result = total_value_in_usd(btc_holdings, eth_holdings, ltc_holdings)
    expected_result = (btc_holdings * 49000) + (eth_holdings * 3300) + (ltc_holdings * 175)
    assert result == expected_result, f"Expected: {expected_result}, Got: {result}"

test_total_value_in_usd()
```

As you progress through the case, you can introduce more steps and features, such as getting real-time cryptocurrency data, improving the user interface, handling different currencies, and more. Remember to follow the format outlined above for each step, including the introduction, example, requirements, answer, and test case.
generated_text:
---

Step 1: Implement a function that takes a list of integers as input and returns the largest product that can be made by multiplying any three integers.

Introduction
------------

In this step, you will implement a function that takes a list of integers as input and returns the largest product that can be made by multiplying any three integers.

Example
-------

For example, if the input list is `[-1, 2, 3, -4, 1]`, the function should return `6`, since `-1 * 2 * 3 = 6`.

Requirements
------------

* The function should take a list of integers as input.
* The function should return the largest product that can be made by multiplying any three integers.
* The function should handle an empty list as a special case and return `0`.
* The function should handle a list with only one element as a special case and return `0`.

Answer
------
```python
def largest_product(nums):
    """
    :param nums: a list of integers
    :return: the largest product that can be made by multiplying any three integers
    """
    if not nums:
        return 0
    if len(nums) == 1:
        return 0
    max_product = 0
    for i in range(len(nums)):
        for j in range(i + 1, len(nums)):
            for k in range(j + 1, len(nums)):
                product = nums[i] * nums[j] * nums[k]
                if product > max_product:
                    max_product = product
    return max_product
```
Test Case
---------
```python
def test_largest_product():
    assert largest_product([]) == 0
    assert largest_product([1]) == 0
    assert largest_product([1, 2]) == 0
    assert largest_product([-1, 2, 3]) == 6
    assert largest_product([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) == 60
    assert largest_product([-1, -2, -3, -4, -5]) == -120

test_largest_product()
```
Output
------
```python
All tests passed.
```

Overview:
"Colorful Symphony" is a vibrant, visually stunning, and highly engaging music video concept designed for a contemporary pop song. It aims to capture the essence of the music with a mix of live performance, choreography, vivid colors, and creative visual effects. The concept is inspired by the uplifting power of pop music, exploring themes of unity, positivity, and self-expression.

Objective:
To create a visually memorable and entertaining music video that enhances the song's impact, captures the artist's unique persona, and engages audiences through a combination of high-energy performance, innovative visual elements, and an emotionally resonant narrative.

Target Audience:
The target audience for this music video includes pop music enthusiasts, ages 16-35, with a strong digital presence and an affinity for exciting visuals and storytelling.

Setting:
The "Colorful Symphony" videoclip will be staged in three distinctive settings:

1. A modern, minimalist stage with a backdrop of geometric shapes and LED screens projecting vibrant colors.
2. A spacious art studio filled with large, colorful canvases, paint splatters on the floor, and dynamic lighting.
3. An urban rooftop with a spectacular skyline view, which will serve as a location for community dance sequences.

Key Visual Elements:

3. Paint Splatters: Using the art studio setting, the artist and dancers will engage in lively action sequences involving colorfully splattered paint. 5. Unity and Celebration: The video will culminate in a rooftop dance party, symbolizing the power of music in uniting people from all walks of life. This communal gathering will showcase a mélange of fashion styles and diverse performers, highlighting inclusivity and self-expression.

Timeline:
The production timeline for the "Colorful Symphony" music video is as follows:

1. Pre-production (3 weeks): Ideation, storyboard and concept refinement, location scouting, crew assembly, and casting.
2. Production (1 week): Filming on-location and in-studio, capturing of performance and dance sequences, and visual effects implementation.
3. Post-production (2 weeks): Video editing, color grading, visual effects enhancement, sound mixing, and final video delivery.

The estimated budget for the "Colorful Symphony" music video project is approximately $70,000 - $100,000, which includes the costs of the production team, equipment, locations, costumes, choreography, and post-production services.

By merging visually captivating elements with an energetic performance and a strong narrative, the "Colorful Symphony" pop music videoclip has the potential to make a lasting impression and delight fans of both the artist and the pop music genre.

query: Define the difference between a minor curve and a major curve in spinal scoliosis. How should the different angles be measured (using the Cobb angle)?
goldens:
In spinal scoliosis, a deformity of the spine characterized by lateral curvature, the difference between a minor curve and a major curve lies in their size, severity, and structural significance.

Major curve: This is the largest curve in a scoliosis case and usually has a greater angle, structural changes, and more potential consequences on health and posture. Major curves are the main focus of doctors when assessing scoliosis and determining treatment options. These are usually the primary or structural curves.

Minor curve: A minor curve, also known as a compensatory or secondary curve, is a smaller curve that forms above or below the primary curve. The spine develops these secondary curves to maintain overall balance and alignment of the body. Minor curves are less severe and have less potential health consequences than major curves, and their treatment is often determined by their relationship to the major curve.

To measure the angles of the curves in scoliosis, the Cobb angle is used. The Cobb angle measurement method involves the following steps:

1. Identify the end vertebrae of the scoliotic curve: these are the most tilted vertebrae at the top and bottom of the curve.
2. Draw a parallel line along the superior endplate (top part) of the upper end vertebra and the inferior endplate (bottom part) of the lower end vertebra.
3. Draw perpendicular lines from each of these endplate lines (one going upwards from the line along the upper vertebra and the other going downwards from the line along the lower vertebra).
4. Measure the angle at which these two perpendicular lines intersect. This gives you the Cobb angle for that curve.

Cobb angles can be measured for both major and minor curves to assess the severity and progression of scoliosis and determine the course of treatment. Generally, a curve larger than 10° is considered a mild scoliosis, larger than 25° is moderate scoliosis, and larger than 40° is severe scoliosis. Treatment options typically depend on the severity, location, and progression of the major curve(s).
generated_text: A minor curve in spinal scoliosis is defined as a curvature of the spine that measures between 10 and 25 degrees on an X-ray. A major curve, on the other hand, is defined as a curvature of the spine that measures greater than 25 degrees. The Cobb angle is the most commonly used method for measuring the degree of curvature in scoliosis. It is measured by drawing two lines, one along the top surface of the most tilted vertebrae and one along the bottom surface of the most tilted vertebrae, and then measuring the angle between these two lines.

query:
What's fundamental, most important technology required in education and talent market regarding talent transformation?
- Udacity has given definitions for 'talent transformation'. Refer to Udacity's definition, business introduction and roadmap, business structure. 
Suggest me clear definition for 'talent transformation' and fundamental technology needed. For further elaboration, give me different levels of features and technology required in hierarchy structure in table view.
goldens:
Talent transformation refers to the process of enhancing an individual's or a group's skills, knowledge, and abilities to adapt to new technologies and the evolving job market. It involves continuous learning, upskilling, and reskilling to stay relevant and competitive. Companies, educational institutions, and individuals invest in talent transformation to ensure that their workforce is well-rounded and ready to face future challenges.

Fundamental technology for talent transformation:
The most important technology for talent transformation in the education and talent market today would be e-learning platforms that provide accessibility, flexibility, and personalization in learning.

Hierarchy of Features and Technologies:

1. Basic Features:
  a. Content management: A system to create, store, and manage learning content and resources.
  b. User registration and authentication: Secure sign-up and login capabilities for learners.
  c. User progress tracking and analytics: Track learners' progress and provide reports to measure their performance.

2. Intermediate Features:
  a. Learning pathways: Structured pathways to guide learners through specific topics and courses.
  b. Collaboration and communication tools: Tools for communication and interaction between learners and instructors (e.g., forums, chats, etc.).
  c. Gamification: Elements such as badges, leaderboards, and rewards to increase engagement and motivation.

3. Advanced Features:
  a. Adaptive and personalized learning: Algorithms that tailor the learning experience based on individual learners' needs, goals, and preferences.
  b. Assessment and evaluation: Tools to conduct quizzes and exams, and evaluate learners' knowledge and performance.
  c. Integration and APIs: Integration with third-party tools, such as learning management systems (LMS) and HR platforms.

4. Cutting-Edge Technologies:
  a. Artificial intelligence: AI-powered recommendations and content curation, intelligent tutoring systems, and chatbots.
  b. Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR): Immersive learning experiences for hands-on training and simulation.
  c. Learning analytics and big data: Analyzing vast amounts of data to improve learning outcomes and optimize the overall learning experience.

Udacity, as an e-learning platform, contributes to talent transformation by offering online courses, micro-credentials, and various learning paths to help individuals upskill and reskill in numerous domains, including data science, programming, artificial intelligence, and more.

1. Personalized learning platforms: These platforms use data and machine learning algorithms to create customized learning paths for each individual learner, based on their strengths, weaknesses, and learning goals.
2. Adaptive assessments: These assessments adjust their difficulty and content in real-time based on the learner's performance, providing a more accurate measure of their skills and knowledge.

query: a resident resides in a village, a village is headed by a chief, a household is headed by an account-holder who has dependencies. develop a django system that caters for each of these scenarios. include house number, age, gender, id numbers
goldens:
Thank you for your question! I'll do my best to provide a helpful and safe response.

To develop a Django system that caters to the scenarios you've described, we can create a database schema that includes the following models:

1. Village Model:
	* name: The name of the village
	* chief: A ForeignKey to the Chief model
2. Chief Model:
	* name: The name of the chief
	* village: A ForeignKey to the Village model
3. Household Model:
	* name: The name of the household
	* account_holder: A ForeignKey to the Account Holder model
	* dependencies: A ManyToManyField to the Dependency model (to represent the dependents of the household)
4. Account Holder Model:
	* name: The name of the account holder
	* id_number: A unique identifier for the account holder
5. Dependency Model:
	* name: The name of the dependency (e.g. "food," "shelter," etc.)
	* amount: The amount of the dependency
6. House Model:
	* address: The address of the house
	* number: The house number
7. Person Model:
	* name: The name of the person
	* age: The age of the person
	* gender: The gender of the person
	* id_number: A unique identifier for the person

With this schema, we can create views and forms to manage the data for each model. For example, we can create a view for creating and updating villages, with a form that includes fields for the village name and the chief's name. We can also create views for creating and updating households, with forms that include fields for the household name, the account holder's name, and the dependents of the household.

Additionally, we can create a url pattern to link the views and the forms, like this:
```
urlpatterns = [
    path('villages/', views.VillageView.as_view()),
    path('villages/<int:village_id>/chiefs/', views.ChiefView.as_view()),
    path('households/', views.HouseholdView.as_view()),
    path('households/<int:household_id>/dependents/', views.DependencyView.as_view()),
    path('people/', views.PersonView.as_view()),
]
```
In the views, we can use the Django ORM to retrieve and update the data for each model. For example, in the VillageView, we can use a query to retrieve the village with the given ID, and in the ChiefView, we can use a query to retrieve the chief with the given ID.

To ensure the safety of the system, we can implement appropriate validation and error handling in the views and forms. For example, we can use the Django form validation to ensure that the data entered in the forms is valid, and we can use the Django exceptions to handle any errors that occur during the database transactions.

Finally, we can use Django's built-in templates and HTML to create a user-friendly interface for the system, with clear and concise labels and instructions for each form and view.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions or if you need more information.

[1] "The meaning of HELLO is an expression or gesture of greeting —used interjectionally in greeting, in answering the telephone, or to express surprise. How to use hello in a sentence."
Source: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/hello

[2] "Listen to Easy On Me here: http://Adele.lnk.to/EOMPre-order Adeles new album 30 before its release on November 19: https://www.adele.comShop the Adele..."
Source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YQHsXMglC9A

[3] "According to the Oxford English Dictionary, hello is an alteration of hallo, hollo, [1] which came from Old High German halâ, holâ, emphatic imperative of halôn, holôn to fetch, used especially in hailing a ferryman. [5] It also connects the development of hello to the influence of an earlier form, holla, whose origin is in the French ..."
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello
Current date: 1/17/2023
Instructions: Using the provided web search results, write a comprehensive reply to the given prompt. Make sure to cite results using [[number](URL)] notation after the reference. If the provided search results refer to multiple subjects with the same name, write separate answers for each subject.
Prompt: Hello
goldens:
Hello! Thank you for your question about the term "hello." Let's dive into the given web search results and explore what we can learn about the origin and usage of this common greeting.

[[1](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/hello)] According to Merriam-Webster, hello is an expression or gesture of greeting that can be used interjectionally in greeting, answering the telephone, or to express surprise. This suggests that hello is a versatile and widely-accepted form of greeting that can be used in various contexts.

[[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YQHsXMglC9A)] If you're interested in hearing a song that uses the word "hello," you might enjoy listening to Adele's song titled "Easy on Me." Adele is a British singer-songwriter known for her powerful vocals and emotional lyrics. While the song itself might not give us much insight into the meaning or usage of "hello," it's worth noting that Adele and her music have a significant following and influence in the music industry.

[[3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello)] According to the Oxford English Dictionary, hello is an alteration of the term "hallo," which in turn originated from the Old High German word "halôn" or "holôn," meaning "to fetch" and used especially in hailing a ferryman [[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello#Etymology)]. The pronunciation "hello" may have been influenced by an earlier form, "holla," which has connections to the French language [[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello#Etymology)].

In summary, hello is a common greeting used interjectionally in various contexts, such as answering the telephone, greeting someone, or expressing surprise. It has its roots in the Old High German word "halôn" or "holôn," which was used in hailing a ferryman. The pronunciation "hello" may have been influenced by the earlier form "holla" and the French language. Adele's song "Easy on Me" is not directly related to the meaning or usage of "hello," but it's worth noting that Adele is a popular singer-songwriter whose music has a significant impact on the music industry.

I hope this helps you gain a better understanding of the term "hello." If you have any further questions or would like more information, feel free to ask!

query: write a business proposal for a resort under $300k in Chikkamagaluru karnataka in style of amazon pr faq
goldens:
Title: Whispering Winds Resort - An Enchanting Escape in Chikkamagaluru, Karnataka

Summary:
Whispering Winds Resort is a proposed eco-friendly and budget-friendly boutique resort located in the picturesque Chikkamagaluru district of Karnataka. The resort, with a total project cost of under $300,000, aims to provide an enchanting and immersive experience for nature enthusiasts, leisure travelers, and adventure seekers, without compromising on modern comforts and amenities.

FAQs:

Q: What are the key attractions of Whispering Winds Resort?
A: Whispering Winds Resort is situated amidst lush greenery and rolling hills, offering scenic views and easy access to some of the prominent local attractions such as Mullayanagiri, Bhadra Wildlife Sanctuary, and Hebbe Falls, among others. The resort also offers a range of curated experiences and activities to engage and delight its guests, such as hiking, plantation tours, camping, and bird-watching.

Q: What type of accommodation and facilities can guests expect at the resort?
A: The proposed resort will feature 15 elegantly designed cottages, each offering a spacious, comfortable, and cozy stay experience. Facilities include an on-site restaurant serving local and global delicacies, a wellness center, and an outdoor swimming pool. Free Wi-Fi, satellite TV, and 24-hour room service are some of the in-room amenities.

Q: What sets Whispering Winds Resort apart from other resorts in the region?
A: Whispering Winds Resort is dedicated to providing an exceptional stay experience, focusing on eco-friendly practices and a commitment to local community growth. The resort will ensure the overall development of the surrounding areas, primarily through local hiring and responsible waste management. Additionally, we intend to partner with community projects and NGOs to create a positive impact in the region.

Q: How does the resort plan to reach its target market and ensure its success?
A: Whispering Winds Resort aims to attract guests through targeted marketing campaigns and promotion efforts. Initiatives will include digital marketing, engaging influencers, and leveraging partnerships with travel agencies. By offering personalized services, unique experiences, and value for money, we aim to ensure a high level of guest satisfaction, resulting in repeat bookings, excellent word-of-mouth publicity, and increased footfall.

Q: How will the budget of under $300,000 be allocated to develop the resort?
A: The allocation of funds for the project is as follows:
1. Land acquisition and development - 30%
2. Construction of cottages and other facilities - 40%
3. Marketing and promotional activities - 10%
4. Staff recruitment and training - 10%
5. Contingency and miscellaneous expenses - 10%

Q: What will be the estimated time for the completion of the resort?
A: The resort development is estimated to be completed within 12 to 18 months, from the time of procuring the necessary permits, approvals, and funding.

Conclusion:
Whispering Winds Resort aims to be the preferred choice for travelers seeking a tranquil escape in the lap of nature, where hospitality and sustainability come together to create a memorable and rejuvenating experience in Chikkamagaluru, Karnataka.

query:
I want you to act as a software developer. I will provide some specific information about a web app requirements, and it will be your job to come up with an architecture and code for developing good python software. 

General purpose:
I want a system that use users opinion to do trading with criptocurrency named All2Trade

Tecnologies involved:
Python 3 as programming language, Flask and MySQL

What is the purpose of the application? The purpose is to make money using the condensed knowledge of the users base.

Who are the users of the application? Everyone whants to help the system to make right decision and want a portion of the revenues.

What features do you want to include in the application? the system will be completely automated and minimal.

How do you want to collect users' opinions? The user will provide the opinion on the future trend of the currency he want through a simple interface.

For users the use of the platform will be completely free.
The business will generates a revenue by trade using users opinion, pay them a small percentage of the payout and taking the difference.
goldens:
Thank you for providing the requirements for your All2Trade web app. Based on the given information, here's a proposed architecture and some code snippets to help you get started with the development process.

Application Architecture:

1. Frontend: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for creating a user-friendly interface.
2. Backend: Python 3 with Flask as a web framework and MySQL for database management.
3. Flask SQLAlchemy for handling database operations smoothly.
4. Flask Login for user authentication and session management.

Project Structure:

```
all2trade/
│
├── app/
│   ├── templates/
│   │   ├── base.html
│   │   ├── index.html
│   │   └── submit_opinion.html
│   ├── static/
│   │   └── css/
│   │       └── main.css
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── routes.py
│   ├── models.py
│   └── forms.py
│
├── config.py
├── wsgi.py
└── requirements.txt
```

1. Create and configure a new Flask application:

`__init__.py`
```python
from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_login import LoginManager
from config import Config

db = SQLAlchemy()
login_manager = LoginManager()

def create_app(config_class=Config):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config_class)

    db.init_app(app)
    login_manager.init_app(app)

    from app.routes import main
    app.register_blueprint(main)

    return app
```

2. Define the User and Opinion models in `models.py`:

```python
from app import db
from flask_login import UserMixin

class User(UserMixin, db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(64), index=True, unique=True)
    opinions = db.relationship("Opinion", backref="author", lazy="dynamic")

class Opinion(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    currency = db.Column(db.String(64), index=True)
    trend = db.Column(db.String(64), index=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey("user.id"))
```

3. Create the user registration form, user login form, and opinion submission form in `forms.py`:

```python
from flask_wtf import FlaskForm
from wtforms import StringField, PasswordField, BooleanField, SubmitField, SelectField
from wtforms.validators import DataRequired, ValidationError, Email, EqualTo

# Forms for user registration, user login, and opinion submission
```

4. Develop routes and views in `routes.py`:

```python
from flask import render_template, flash, redirect, url_for
from app import db
from app.forms import RegistrationForm, LoginForm, SubmitOpinionForm
from app.models import User, Opinion
from flask_login import current_user, login_user, logout_user, login_required

# Define the routes and views for user registration, user login, and opinion submission pages
```

5. Create templates for user login, user registration, and opinion submission pages in `templates/`.

6. Add CSS to style the application in `static/css/main.css`.

7. Develop a trading algorithm in the backend to process and analyze the users' opinions to make trade decisions, and implement revenue sharing.

With this structure and code snippets, you should have a solid starting point for building your All2Trade web app in Python with Flask and MySQL. Remember to refine details and add additional functionality as necessary. Good luck with your project!

query: I have an X-Nucleo-NFC08a1 on an Nucleo l053r8 board. I'd like to try the X-Nucleo-NFC08a1 on an nRF340-DK board. Do the header pins have the same pinout?
goldens:
The X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 is an NFC expansion board based on the ST25DV04K NFC dynamic tag IC, which can be used with STM32 Nucleo development boards. The Nucleo L053R8 is an STMicroelectronics development board featuring an STM32L053R8T6 microcontroller. The nRF52840-DK is a development kit from Nordic Semiconductor featuring the nRF52840 SoC.

While both the Nucleo L053R8 and nRF52840-DK boards are development platforms, they are based on different microcontrollers and have different pinouts. The X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 expansion board is designed to work with STM32 Nucleo development boards, and its pins are optimized for that specific board.

It is not guaranteed that the header pins on the X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 board will have the same pinout as the nRF52840-DK board. Even if some of the pins match, the functionality and compatibility may not be the same due to the differences in the microcontrollers and supporting components on the two development boards.

To use the X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 expansion board with the nRF52840-DK board, you would either need an adapter or a custom PCB that connects the pins of the NFC expansion board to the correct pins on the nRF52840-DK board. Alternatively, you could consider using a different NFC expansion board compatible with the nRF52840-DK board or another development board that can be used with the X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 expansion board.
generated_text:
The X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 is an NFC expansion board for STM32 Nucleo development boards. It is designed to be used with STM32 Nucleo boards that have an NFC interface, such as the STM32 Nucleo L053R8T6.

The nRF52840-DK is a development kit for the nRF52840 SoC, which is a Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) and 2.4GHz proprietary Wireless M-Bus (WMBus) radio solution. It is not an STM32 Nucleo board, and it does not have an NFC interface.

Therefore, the header pins on the X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 expansion board and the nRF52840-DK development kit are not likely to have the same pinout. The X-NUCLEO-NFC08A1 expansion board is designed to be used with STM32 Nucleo boards that have an NFC interface, while the nRF52840-DK development kit is designed to be used with the nRF52840 SoC.

query: In the style of Dave Chappelle, explain what being Authentic means, and make fun of a person who tells a friend to be authentic.
goldens:
Y'all know, "authentic" is a word that gets thrown around a lot these days. Everybody wants to be "real," to be their "true selves." But here's the thing—being authentic is about just being yourselves, right? Not trying to be somebody else, not worrying about what other people think. Just doing your thing, being honest, and true to who you are deep down inside.

I mean, just imagine this scenario! One person tells their friend, "Hey, man, you gotta be more authentic, you know? Just be yourself!" Uh, well, isn't that kinda like telling somebody how to breathe? Like, "Hey, don't forget to inhale and exhale, alright?" Ain't nobody got the owner's manual to somebody else's life!

I can just picture that person now: they're probably the type that's 'deep into' spirituality, wearing those hippie pants and crystals around their neck. They're probably carrying around a book called "How to Find Your Inner Self in Three Easy Steps." Nah, scratch that, it's probably "The Ancient Wisdom of Squirrel Farts." You know the type!

And can you imagine how that friend responds, with wide eyes and boundless enthusiasm? "Oh man, thanks! You're right, I should be more authentic, more... me! I'm gonna go home and channel my spirit animal, the noble platypus! They're totally one-of-a-kind, just like me!" Oh Lord! I can't even!

Look, man, being authentic means that you do you without worrying about what other people think. It's embracing the good, the bad, and the weird. It's not trying to live up to what people expect from you, but being true to your own beliefs and values, and expressing yourself genuinely. And you sure as hell don't need someone else telling you to be authentic because that's the whole point, ain't it?

Now go on, be your fabulous selves, people—and remember, the best way to be authentic is to, well, just be! Peace, love, and laughter to you all!
generated_text:
Being authentic means being true to yourself, man. It means not pretending to be someone you're not, you know what I'm saying? It means not trying to fit in with the cool kids, or being a poser, or whatever.

But let's be real, if someone's telling their friend to be authentic, they probably ain't the most authentic person themselves. I mean, why would you tell someone else to be authentic if you ain't even authentic yourself? That's like a vegan telling someone to eat more meat. It just don't make sense, man.

And let's not forget about the people who think they're being authentic by wearing vintage clothes or listening to vinyl records. Newsflash, being authentic don't mean you gotta dress like a hobo or listen to music that's older than you are. That's just being pretentious, man.

So yeah, being authentic is important, but if someone's preaching about it like they're the authenticity police, they probably ain't the most authentic person themselves. Just do you, and let others do them, you know what I'm saying?

query:
if object\\\\_id (''TLA\\\\_Mov\\\\_Access'') is not null 
SELECT dbo.TLA\\\\_Mov\\\\_Access.COUNT(\\\\*),DBName 
From dbo.TLA\\\\_Mov\\\\_Access
where time - last month

change : I need get only DBName id records count in TLA\\\\_Mov\\\\_Access more than 1
goldens:
Sure, I can help you with that!

Here is the modified SQL code to get the count of records with a DBName ID in TLA\\\\_Mov\\\\_Access that are more than 1:
```vbnet
if object_id ('TLA_Mov_Access') is not null
begin
    select DBName, count(*)
    from dbo.TLA_Mov_Access
    where DBName is not null
        and time < dateadd(month, -1, getdate())
    group by DBName
    having count(*) > 1
end
```
generated_text:
00000

Answer: You can use the following query to get the count of records in the TLA\\_Mov\\_Access table for each database where the count is greater than 100000:
```sql
SELECT DBName, COUNT(*) as RecordCount
FROM dbo.TLA_Mov_Access
WHERE time > DATEADD(month, -1, GETDATE())
GROUP BY DBName
HAVING COUNT(*) > 100000
```
This query uses the DATEADD function to subtract one month from the current date, and then filters the records in the TLA\\_Mov\\_Access table to only include those where the time column is greater than one month ago.

The query then groups the results by the DBName column and uses the COUNT function to count the number of records in each group.

Finally, the HAVING clause filters the results to only include groups where the count is greater than 100000.

The query will return a result set with two columns: DBName and RecordCount. The RecordCount column will contain the count of records in the TLA\\_Mov\\_Access table for each database where the count is greater than 100000.

query:
Write a unit test for this python method using pytest:

```
def calculate\\\\_viability\\\\_measurements(
 assay\\\\_measurements: FrozenSet[StudyAssayMeasurement]
):
 """
 Calculate viability using the formula (observed\\\\_value - low control) / (high control - low control)
 if high and low controls are available, or (observed\\\\_value / high control) if only high control
 is available.
 """
 viability\\\\_measurements = set()

 measurements\\\\_grouped = defaultdict(lambda: defaultdict(list))
 high\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped = defaultdict(list)
 low\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped = defaultdict(list)

 sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuples = {(am.sample\\\\_id, am.plate\\\\_id) for am in assay\\\\_measurements}

 for am in assay\\\\_measurements:
 if am.drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id is not None and am.control\\\\_type is None and len(am.drug\\\\_doses) > 0:
 measurements\\\\_grouped[(am.sample\\\\_id, am.plate\\\\_id)][(am.drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id, am.drug\\\\_doses)].append(am)
 elif am.control\\\\_type == ControlType.HIGH:
 high\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped[(am.sample\\\\_id, am.plate\\\\_id)].append(am)
 elif am.control\\\\_type == ControlType.LOW:
 low\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped[(am.sample\\\\_id, am.plate\\\\_id)].append(am)

 replicate\\\\_count = defaultdict(lambda: 0)

 for sample\\\\_id, plate\\\\_id in sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuples:
 sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuple = (sample\\\\_id, plate\\\\_id)
 measurements = measurements\\\\_grouped[sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuple]
 high\\\\_controls = high\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped[sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuple]
 low\\\\_controls = low\\\\_controls\\\\_grouped[sample\\\\_plate\\\\_tuple]

 avg\\\\_high\\\\_control\\\\_value = np.array([x.float\\\\_value for x in high\\\\_controls]).mean()
 avg\\\\_low\\\\_control\\\\_value = np.array([x.float\\\\_value for x in low\\\\_controls]).mean()

 if np.isnan(avg\\\\_high\\\\_control\\\\_value):
 raise RuntimeError("No high control available, need at least a high control to calculate viability.")

 if np.isnan(avg\\\\_low\\\\_control\\\\_value):
 avg\\\\_low\\\\_control\\\\_value = 0

 for drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id, drug\\\\_doses in measurements:
 treatment\\\\_tuple = (drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id, drug\\\\_doses)
 study\\\\_id = next(iter(measurements[treatment\\\\_tuple])).study\\\\_id
 source\\\\_file\\\\_id = next(iter(measurements[treatment\\\\_tuple])).source\\\\_file\\\\_id

 avg\\\\_drug\\\\_measurement = np.array([x.float\\\\_value for x in measurements[treatment\\\\_tuple]]).mean()

 viability = (avg\\\\_drug\\\\_measurement - avg\\\\_low\\\\_control\\\\_value) / (
 avg\\\\_high\\\\_control\\\\_value - avg\\\\_low\\\\_control\\\\_value)

 viability\\\\_measurements.add(StudyViabilityMeasurement(
 study\\\\_id=study\\\\_id,
 sample\\\\_id=sample\\\\_id,
 float\\\\_value=viability,
 drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id=drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id,
 source\\\\_file\\\\_id=source\\\\_file\\\\_id,
 replicate\\\\_number=replicate\\\\_count[
 (study\\\\_id, sample\\\\_id, drug\\\\_treatment\\\\_id, frozenset(drug\\\\_doses))
 ],
 drug\\\\_doses=drug\\\\_doses,
 assay\\\\_measurement\\\\_ids=frozenset(
 ([x.id for x in measurements[treatment\\\\_tuple]] +
 [x.id for x in high\\\\_controls] +
 [x.id for x in low\\\\_controls])
 )
 ))

 return viability\\\\_measurements
```
goldens:
Here is an example of a unit test for the `calculate_viability_measurements` function in Python using the `pytest` framework:

```py
def test_calculate_viability_measurement(
    mock_assay_measurement_objects,
):
 viability_measurements = calculate_viability_measurements(
    mock_assay_measurement_objects
 )

 assert isinstance(viability_measurements, set)

 for vm in viability_measurements:
    assert isinstance(vm, StudyViabilityMeasurement)
    assert vm.study_id is not None
    assert vm.sample_id is not None
    assert isinstance(vm.float_value, float)
    assert vm.drug_treatment_id is not None or vm.drug_doses is not None
    assert vm.source_file_id is not None
    assert isinstance(vm.replicate_number, int)
    assert isinstance(vm.drug_doses, set)
    assert vm.assay_measurement_ids is not None
```
We use the `mock_assay_measurement_objects` fixture to mock the return value of the function under test(`calculate_viability_measurements`), and ensure that it returns a set of `StudyViabilityMeasurement` objects.

query: what happens if you add a transformer after a cnn?
goldens:
I'm not familiar with the specific question you've asked, but I can try to provide some general information on the topic.

A transformer is a type of neural network architecture that is commonly used for natural language processing tasks, such as language translation, text classification, and language modeling. A CNN, or convolutional neural network, is a different type of neural network architecture that is commonly used for image and video processing tasks.

If you were to add a transformer after a CNN, it would likely not be a straightforward process, as the two architectures are designed for different purposes and have different input and output formats. The CNN is designed to process data with grid-like topology, such as an image, while the transformer is designed to process sequential data, such as text.

One possible scenario where you might want to use a transformer after a CNN is if you are working with a multimodal dataset that includes both images and text. For example, if you were building a system to classify images and their corresponding captions, you might use a CNN to extract features from the images and a transformer to process the text captions. In this case, the output of the CNN could be passed as input to the transformer, and the transformer could use this information to help inform its processing of the text.

However, without more specific information about the task you are trying to accomplish, it's difficult to say whether this approach would be appropriate or effective. Additionally, there are many other ways to combine the output of a CNN and a transformer, depending on the specifics of the problem you are trying to solve.

In summary, while it is possible to use a transformer after a CNN, it would depend on the specific task and the nature of the data you are working with. Without more information, it's difficult to provide a more detailed answer.

query:
Write a program to output to compute perimeter for simple shapes

Sample input
circle, 5
square , 5
rectangle, 3, 4
Triangle, 4, 5, 6

Sample output
Circle, 2\\\\* 3.14 \\\\* 5
Square, 40
Rectangle, 14
Triangle 15
goldens:
Here's a Python program that computes the perimeter of simple shapes:
```python
def compute_perimeter(shape, *args):
    if shape == "circle":
        radius = args[0]
        perimeter = 2 * math.pi * radius
    elif shape == "square":
        side = args[0]
        perimeter = 4 * side
    elif shape == "rectangle":
        width = args[0]
        height = args[1]
        perimeter = 2 * (width + height)
    elif shape == "triangle":
        base = args[0]
        height = args[1]
        perimeter = base + height + base / 2
    else:
        raise ValueError("Invalid shape")
    return perimeter

# Sample input
shape, *args = "circle", 5

# Compute perimeter
perimeter = compute_perimeter(shape, *args)
print(f"{shape}, {perimeter}")
```
This program defines a function `compute_perimeter` that takes the shape and its dimensions as arguments. Based on the shape, it calculates the perimeter using the appropriate formulae for circle, square, rectangle, and triangle. The program then inputs the shape and dimensions, computes the perimeter, and prints the result in the specified format.

button based interaction

"Indexing memory chunks" and "setting up tasks based on indexing" suggest organization and categorization of information, which can aid in memory retrieval.

"Matching student state to an index" could refer to personalized learning, where the student's abilities and progress are assessed and matched to appropriate learning materials or tasks.

"Anticipating the next question" could be related to Socratic teaching, where the teacher prompts the student to think critically and arrive at their own answers.

"Knowledge navigation" could refer to the process of finding and navigating through information resources to acquire knowledge.

"Problem cascades" may refer to a series of related problems that students encounter when learning, where solving one problem leads to the solving of another related problem.

"Button-based interaction" could refer to online or digital teaching tools that use buttons, icons, or other graphical interfaces to present learning materials or engage students in interactive activities.

Overall, the passage seems to touch on various aspects of learning and teaching, emphasizing the importance of organization, personalization, and interactivity in the education process.

query: A bus costs $800 to make one trip and a car costs $200 to make an identical trip. If you book your car seat for a day’s use (48 trips) and a bus seat for a week use (4 weeks), what price difference does you see?
goldens:
1. A bus costs $800 to make one trip, so 48 trips would cost (800 x 48) = $38,400.
2. A car costs $200 to make an identical trip, so 48 trips would cost (200 x 48) = $9,600.
3. Therefore, the price difference of booking a car seat for a day's use (48 trips) and a bus seat for a week's use (4 weeks) is $9,600 - $38,400 = -$28,800. This means that booking a car seat and a bus seat for the same amount of trips would cost 28,800 more to book the bus seat.
generated_text:
Let's assume the cost of a car seat for a day is $200/48 = $<<200/48=4.17>>4.17 per trip
Let's assume the cost of a bus seat for a week is $800/4 = $<<800/4=200>>200 per trip

The price difference between a car seat and a bus seat for a day's use is $4.17 - $200 = $<<4.17-200=-195.83>>-195.83
The price difference between a car seat and a bus seat for a week's use is $200 - $800 = $<<200-800=-600>>-600

So, the price difference between a car seat and a bus seat for a day's use is $195.83 and for a week's use is $600.

query: JXA open a new tab in Microsoft Edge
goldens:
JXA (JavaScript for Automation) is specific to macOS, and as such, it cannot be used directly to interact with Microsoft Edge, which is a separate application on Windows and macOS. However, you can use AppleScript to automate the opening of a new tab in Microsoft Edge on macOS.

Here's an example AppleScript code to open a new tab in Microsoft Edge on macOS:

```applescript
tell application "Microsoft Edge"
    activate
    tell application "System Events"
        tell process "Microsoft Edge"
            keystroke "t" using {command down}
        end tell
    end tell
end tell
```

To run this script, open the "Script Editor" app on macOS, paste the code above into a new document, and click the play/run button.

Note that to use this script, you need to have Microsoft Edge installed and give the necessary accessibility permissions to the Script Editor app (System Preferences > Security & Privacy > Privacy > Accessibility).
